metadata.title: Neck Pain, Chronic  Whiplash
anatomical location body part affected: Neck/cervical bony elements (often facet joints), disks, fascia, CNS, muscle (e.g., deep cervical flexors, upper trapezius, sternocleidomastoid), and ligaments
description: Whiplash is the mechanism (i.e., acceleration-deceleration)  of neck injury that usually results from a vehicle-related  crash. Whiplash-associated  disorder (WAD) is a bony or soft-tissue  whiplash injury characterized by a variety of clinical manifestations. In chronic whiplash (CW) cases, the symptoms have persisted longer than 3 months(1)

The Quebec task force created a classification system of the whiplash injury:(36) -Grade 0: No pain or physical symptoms -Grade 1: Neck pain, stiffness, or tenderness but no physical symptoms -Grade 2: Neck pain and musculoskeletal symptoms (e.g., decreased ROM, point tenderness) -Grade 3: Neck pain and associated neurological symptoms (e.g., sensory deficits, decreased deep tendon reflexes, muscle weakness) -Grade 4: Neck pain with fracture/dislocation

Soft-tissue  neck pain with increased sensitivity to both painful and innocuous stimuli is characteristic of CW. This hypersensitivity also commonly involves the upper trapezius and other shoulder muscles(1,2)
Moderately strong evidence supports neck-specific  therapeutic exercise for pain management and functional rehabilitation to reduce disability in patients with CW symptoms(1,2)

Complications associated with CW pain include stress reactions (e.g., dizziness, tinnitus, vision changes, poor concentration or memory, occipital headaches, sleep disturbances, anxiety, depression, hypochondriasis) of uncertain etiology.(36)Treatments for such persistent neuropsychological whiplash symptoms are not covered in this Clinical Review

S13.S13.40: (WAD1) with complaint of neck pain, stiffness, or tenderness only
S13.S13.41: (WAD2) with complaint of neck pain with musculoskeletal signs
S13.S13.42: (WAD3) with complaint of neck pain with neurological signs

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Use caution with nonfinalized cases of workers’ compensation and third-party insurance claims
presentation signs and symptoms: Symptoms of whiplash injury continuing > 3 months after acute whiplash(1)

History of an acceleration-deceleration  injury. Most injuries occur during a rear-end  motor vehicle accident (MV A), but other mechanisms are possible (e.g., sports accident, physical abuse, or other trauma)(35,36)
Most common symptoms are neck pain and stiffness and pain in the back, shoulders, and/or temporomandibular joints(37)

Additional symptoms may include:(1,34,35,37) –tenderness, myofascial trigger points, pressure pain, muscle spasms, and/or thermal hyperalgesia in soft tissue of the neck and sometimes the upper shoulders –impaired cervical mobility and ROM –numbness, tingling –occipital headaches –dizziness –visual disturbances –sleep disturbances –fatigue –anxiety –depression –memory difficulties –psychological distress

Patients experiencing temporomandibular disorders (TMD) with a history of whiplash may have increased symptoms of TMD (limited jaw mobility, increase in TMD pain, increase in headaches and stress)(24) –Please see  Clinical Review ... Temporomandibular Disorders  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708575for more detail Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: In addition to the neck, other painful sites (i.e., the shoulders, upper back, mid-back,  low back, and buttocks) should be included in the assessment and treatment
Cervical spine surgery: obtain specific orders from the surgeon; often, manual assessment (especially of joint mobility) will be restricted

Consult with referring physician immediately on positive findings for: –spinal derangement -Spurling’s test. See  special tests   under Examination -Jackson’s compression test. See  special tests   under Examination -Bakody’s (shoulder abduction) test. See  special tests   under Examination –upper motor neuron disease -Hoffmann’s sign -Babinski sign –vertebral artery test –atlanto-axial  ligamentous instability

causes ,,: High-energy  cervical trauma secondary to uncontrolled hyperflexion-hyperextension(1,35)
The mechanism of injury is typically a rear-end  MV A that generates rapid acceleration/deceleration of the head and uppertorso
Physical abuse such as violent shaking of shoulders may cause whiplash, especially in small children
High-velocity  collision in contact sports (e.g., football, soccer, basketball, wrestling)
pathogenesis: Although cervical spinal injury can occur, bony involvement (e.g., facet joint derangement) is seldom found on plainradiographs or MRI even in unexplained neck pain(1,39)

Patients with CW demonstrate altered central processing of pain and other stimuli:–Authors of a 2013 systematic review (22 trials) found moderate evidence for central sensitization in patients with CWpain(16)–Authors of a study (N = 31) evaluated patients with chronic pain and central sensitization after whiplash. Theyinvestigated the patients’ peripheral pain thresholds after receiving either an injection of a single myofascial trigger pointor other tender point with a local anesthetic or a sham injection. Improvements in peripheral pressure pain thresholds wereseen only after receiving the anesthetic injection(38)–Authors of a 2013 systematic review (27 trials) and meta-analysis  (13 trials) found that individuals with chronic WADshowed heightened sensitivity according to the following tests: pressure-pain  threshold of the head(H)/neck (N)/upperthorax (UT), upper limb (UL), lower limb (LL), flexor withdrawal, cold pain threshold of the H/N/UT and UL, heat painthreshold of the H/N/UT, electrocutaneous stimulation of the H/N/UT and LL, and elbow extension with the brachialplexus provocation test(17)–Researchers of a case-control  study (N = 61) in Belgium found no differences in autonomic responses (i.e., heart rate[HR], skin conductance, and HR variability) to acute painful stimuli using an arm pressure cuff between patients withchronic WAD and healthy controls. They concluded that acute pain associated with the autonomic nervous system isunrelated to the pain or endogenous analgesia associated with CW(19)–Cervical tender points or myofascial trigger points may develop(26)–Subtle changes in balance reactions have been reported in patients with CW and there is a tendency for dizziness/vertigo(3,15)
risk factors: Delaying treatment for whiplash-related  acute neck pain(2)
Patients who expect “never to get better” or “don’t know if they will get better” have increased risk of developing at leastone sign of WAD, 3 months after their collision(5)
Rheumatoid arthritis: Increased risk of cervical spine injury after any trauma to the neck(34)

overall contraindications precautions: History of chronic or recurrent neck pain prior to acute whiplash injury
Cervical spine surgery, unless there are specific orders for treatment from surgeon
Signs of acute illness (e.g., fever, chills, night sweats, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)
Signs of spinal cord injury (e.g., central cord syndrome)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: In addition to the neck, other painful sites (i.e., the shoulders, upper back, mid-back,  low back, and buttocks) should be included in the assessment and treatment
Cervical spine surgery: obtain specific orders from the surgeon; often, manual assessment (especially of joint mobility) will be restricted

Consult with referring physician immediately on positive findings for: –spinal derangement -Spurling’s test. See  special tests   under Examination -Jackson’s compression test. See  special tests   under Examination -Bakody’s (shoulder abduction) test. See  special tests   under Examination –upper motor neuron disease -Hoffmann’s sign -Babinski sign –vertebral artery test –atlanto-axial  ligamentous instability

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document how and when the injury occurred. To be classified as CW, the onset must be associated with high-energy  cervical trauma, as in an MV A or sport injury, with symptoms that have persisted for > 3 months. How have the symptoms progressed since onset? Were there any concurrent injuries (e.g., traumatic brain injury [TBI], fractures)?

course of treatment.medical management: Document interventions tried and the current treatment plan for this patient Without specific orders from a physician, cervical spine surgery is a contraindication to physical therapy intervention for CWDetermine what medications were prescribed, whether they are currently being taken, and, if so, whether they are helping Acetaminophen, NSAIDs, and/or muscle relaxers are commonly prescribed for pain relief(34) Authors of a 2016 systematic review found oral NSAIDS to be more effective at treating neck pain associated disorders (NAD) and for chronic low back pain compared to placebo(27) Chronic pain should be managed by pain management specialists(34) Sleep disturbances may be treated with agents such as zolpidem (Ambien), clonazepam (Klonopin), and trazodone (Desyrel) Corticosteroid or lidocaine injection for unremitting localized pain
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Document the findings on plain radiographs, MRI or other imaging studies of the cervical spine and soft tissue, and any EMG studies
Radiography is recommended when high-risk factors are present. Cervical X-rays  include anteroposterior, lateral, and
MRI is not typically necessary. It is recommended only if neurological deficits are present or ligamentous injury is suspected(34)

Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  compared cervical spine findings on MRI in patients with WAD to asymptomatic controls. Because the quality of evidence was low and no group differences were found,they concluded that the significance of cervical spine MRI findings is not clearly defined(39)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., massage, acupuncture) and whether they help. Does the patient wear a cervical collar? Does the patient use a neck traction device?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Has the patient received occupational or physical therapy for this or related conditions? If so, what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating factors usually include sustaining neck positions at work or home in poor posture and/or alignment. Easing factors may involve stretching and relaxing the neck by lying down. How long before symptoms come on or are eased with each factor?
history of present illness.body chart: Use a body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: The pain is more often constant vs intermittent, dull vs sharp, and aching. Is there numbness or a tingling sensation? Does the neck feel stiff in certain directions? Are there tender points? Where are these symptoms located? Does the pain radiate? Any dizziness or tinnitus? Any problems chewing or swallowing?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: If present, document the usual number of wakings/night. Inquire about the sleeping position and number of pillows used
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., severe headaches, night sweats, swelling, rash) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________ (e.g., foreign language)

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about coexisting problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and musculoskeletal disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken for other problems (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask about other symptoms that have affected the patient’s mobility

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently on work disability? Does the patient participate in vigorous recreational activities or sports? Does the patient’s occupation contribute to symptoms? If so, how?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient report any impairment with ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home (stairs, number of floors in home, lack of caregivers) and whether any modifications are necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Assess height, weight and BMI, leg-length  discrepancy
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient for trial of orthopedic pillow, particularly in cases of sleep disturbance with severe morning neck pain and stiffness
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess balance in sitting, standing, and walking up and down stairs. Use Berg Balance Scale, as indicated, as well as Romberg test (eyes open vs eyes closed) and single-limb stance for higher-level  patientsAssess myotomes of neck and upper extremity elevation (C4), shoulder abduction (C5), elbow flexion/wrist extension (C6), elbow extension/wrist flexion (C7), thumb extension/ulnar deviation (C8), hand intrinsics (T1)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulses. Assess HR and BPAssess body mechanics and posture at workstation (as indicated), as well as during functional mobility, ADLs, etc. Would the patient benefit from an ergonomic assessment?
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability in bed mobility and transfers; use functional independence measure (FIM) for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess neck movements during gait in slow walk. Observe for abnormal head motion or trunk sway as patient turns and rotates head,(4) as well as for any other gait deviations. Assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) as indicatedAssess mobility of cervical and thoracic spine as appropriate (refer to physician orders for patients who have had surgery)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength in cervical flexion, extension, lateral flexion, and rotation with manual muscle testing (MMT). Also assess upper-extremity  strength and shoulder elevation (“shrug”), and grip strength with hand dynamometer as indicated. Expect muscle inhibition and pain-related  weakness
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess responses to touch, pinprick, vibration, and cold in painful sites •Palpation:  Assess for:
tenderness in neck, upper back muscles, and cervical joints using V AS
tight and hard cervical muscles with fibrous adhesions or contraction knots
tender/trigger points in the superficial cervical muscles (trapezius, levator scapulae, anterior and medial scalenes, semispinalis capitis, sternocleidomastoid)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment and position of the head, neck, shoulders, thoracic spine, and scapulae in sitting and standing. Inspect for loss of normal cervical lordosis and excessive thoracic kyphosis
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM of the cervical spine in sitting. Unwillingness to move head because of pain is a red flag suggestive of spinal derangement. Also assess for normal symmetry and rhythm of scapulothoracic ROM
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess upper-extremity  deep tendon reflexesAssess limitations due to pain/ dysfunction
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Dizziness Handicap Inventory (DHI), if indicated(6)This questionnaire has 10 self-report  items covering ADLs, ability to concentrate, and pain(7) for patients with symptoms that affect their upper extremitiesWith patient in supine, examiner moves the patient’s head into cervical extension and lateral flexion; examiner then rotates head to same side and holds position for 30 seconds; test positive if patient’s referred symptoms increase, patient experiences dizziness, dysphagia, or diplopia, or nystagmus is provokedTo assess integrity of the transverse ligament/upper cervical spine instability. With patient sitting, have patient perform a slight cervical nod. The examiner places one hand on the forehead and applies a posterior directed force, with the other hand stabilizing the spinous process of C2. There should be a firm end-feel. A positive test occurs if there is a sliding movement of the head or a decrease in symptoms by increasing the vertebral canal space –Cranio-cervical  flexion test (CCFT)(8) -Use to assess activation and isometric endurance of the deep cervical flexors -Performed in the supine position. Multiple stages of test, with the patient guided to each stage by feedback from a pressure sensor placed behind the neck –To rule out spinal derangement -Jackson’s compression test – with patient sitting, examiner presses straight down on the patient’s head, which is rotated to one side and then the other; test positive if pain radiates into the arm on the side that head is rotated -Spurling’s test–  with patient sitting, examiner presses straight down on the patient’s head, which is flexed to one side and then the other; test positive if pain radiates into the arm on side that head is flexed -Bakody’s shoulder abduction test–  with patient supine or sitting, examiner passively places the patient’s hand on the patient’s head; test positive if the patient’s referred symptoms decrease -Hoffmann’s sign (finger flexor test) – examiner taps or flicks the terminal phalanx or nail of the 3rd or 4th finger; test positive if terminal phalanx of thumb flexes (usually positive in central cord compression) -Auscultation–  examiner listens with stethoscope for crepitus around spinous processes during cervical ROM (this test may differentiate spinal derangement from osteoarthritis)

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Patients commonly have hypersensitivity to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement of cold packs over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Application over infected areas where infection may spread, or cross-contamination  may occur
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor is present in the area
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Individuals who cannot communicate effectively (i.e., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls due to the potential for dizziness/vertigo. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Physical therapists (PT) should prescribe programs on an individual basis to address patient-specific  impairments rather than using a generic program
Modify treatment to avoid increasing pain intensity

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols; many physicians restrict manual interventions for postoperative patients

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgement in their assessment and treatment decisions

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(10)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use:(10)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CW injury/pain, reduced neck ROM and strength, abnormal cervical movement, poor posture and body mechanics, poor workstation setup, work disability
assessment plan of care.rule out: Direct trauma, spinal cord injury, fracture/dislocation, osteoarthritis, degenerative/herniated cervical disc disease, cervical radiculitis/radiculopathy, shoulder impingement, fibromyalgia, infection/inflammation, malignancy, congenital cervical malformation (e.g., Klippel-Feil  syndrome), rheumatoid arthritis, migraine, malingerer/secondary gains, mechanical neck pain
prognosis: Prognosis varies, often based on severity of WAD. Full recovery is possible, but once the condition becomes chronic CW pain is often refractory to conservative treatment(1,34,36)

Authors of a systematic review assessed which psychological factors are important in the development of CW symptoms.Negative expectations of recovery, posttraumatic stress symptoms, and passive coping styles were moderately associated with WAD chronicity(40)

Prognostic factors associated with increased risk for development of CW: female, lower limb pain or nonorganic signs on presentation, has returned to work, has retained a lawyer, or has undergone previous spinal surgery(11) –Based on records of 5,581 individuals with MV A injuries treated by physiotherapy and rehabilitation service providers in Canada –Reduced risk was associated with neck or mid-back  pain on presentation and having modified duties upon return to work

Patients with CW who are on work disability are less likely to return to work due to other musculoskeletal disorders (back pain, muscle pain)(25) –Following WAD, 44%–70%  of patients return to work after one year(41)

Patients who have a grade 2 WAD 5 years after the incident are more likely to be dissatisfied with their overall health (39.4%; p < 0.05) compared to those with a grade 1 WAD (27%) and they also have lower scores in the physical and psychological domains on the quality of life questionnaire(28)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Pain management specialist for severe recalcitrant pain; physician for headache, trigger point injection; ergonomist for workplace evaluation; acupuncturist for pain; personal trainer for home/gym exercise supervision; psychologist for anxiety/depression, PTSD
other considerations: No specific exercise protocol has been found superior for treating CW. The exercise prescription should be individualized to address abnormal cervical movement patterns such as reduced acceleration and velocity, reduced smoothness, and irregular axes of rotation(9)

Researchers of an RCT in Spain found no immediate changes after first rib mobilization to neural or mechanosensitivity in subjects (N = 53) with cervical or cervicobrachial pain after CW when compared to placebo(31) ›Alternative Treatment

Researchers of a randomized crossover trial (N = 39 persons with chronic WAD) with blinded assessors in Belgium found that pressure-pain  sensitivity decreased in the neck and calf after one session of traditional Chinese acupuncture compared to controls who received relaxation therapy. It was hypothesized that acupuncture may activate endogenous analgesic mechanisms suppressed in CW injury(18)
Authors of a 2013 systematic review found limited evidence for acupuncture treatment for patients with CW(23)

An updated systematic review and meta-analysis  is currently underway to evaluate the effectiveness and safety for acupuncture treatment for patients with CW. There has not been a review that had no language restrictions. Most reviews in the past have been limited to English. This review will help to avoid potential language bias when evaluating the studies(37)

Authors of a review analyzed Korean clinical studies that usedpharmacopuncture for whiplash injury following MV As.Pharmacopuncture is a traditional Korean treatment that combines acupuncture and herbal medicine. They found that the most common types of pharmacopuncture used in the studies were Hwangryun-haedoktang,  bee venom, and Jungsong-ouhyul.  The target points most used were Jianjing, Frengchi, and Ashi. They did not evaluate the effectiveness of these treatments in this study(42)
treatment summary: In the acute stage of whiplash injury (first 12 weeks) the Australian national guidelinesrecommend the following treatments: encourage patients to stay active, return to normal activities,and exercise (ROM exercises, low-load  isometric, postural endurance, and strengthening exercises). Evidence is not as strong for the following treatments: manual therapy, thoracic manipulation, acupuncture, kinesiology taping, and trigger-point needling(21)

Moderate evidence supports early mobilization andindividually tailored, supervised progressive aerobic and neck strengthening exercises (as tolerated) to reduce pain and increase functional capacity in patients with CW, provided that exercise training strategies include prevention of symptom flares(2,12,22,32,36)

Therapeutic exercise –Authors of a 2014 systematic review of 10 RCTs suggest that supervised programs that combine neck strengthening and flexibility exercises are effective for the management of chronic neck pain(22) –In a study, subjects with WAD did not respond differently from subjects with mechanical neck pain to manual therapy and exercise in the short term(30)  -Twenty-two  subjects with mechanical neck pain and 28 with WAD participated in a study in Italy. Each received 6 sessions of specific neck exercises and manual therapy. Both groups had similar improvements in cervical ROM –A large multicenter RCT in Sweden recruited 216 patients with chronic WAD between February2011 and May 2012. This RCT evaluated the effect of three different treatment strategies(2,29,41,44,45) -Main inclusion criteria: Chronic WAD, WAD score of 2 or 3, NDI score of at least 10/50, and a V AS greater than 20/100 for the preceding week. Some studies added inclusion criteria and evaluated that data set separately -Treatment groups (12-week  intervention period) -PT-led  neck-specific  exercise group (NSE):Patients met 2 times per week with the PT to perform neck exercises that began with unresisted isometric cervical flexion, extension, and rotation. These exercises were progressed to low isometric resistance and then to neck-specific  gym exercises. Patients received postural instruction and home exercise programs with resistance bands -PT-led  neck-specific  exercise group with abehavior approach (NSEB): Patients received the same treatment as the NSE group with the addition of pain management education and behavioral activities (e.g., goal setting) -Prescription of physical activity (PPA): Patientsreceived instruction to perform general physical activity of their choice outside the healthcare system. Specific neck exercises were not given. They received one call from a PT for encouragement to continue staying active -Primary study outcomes were published in 2015 and evaluated self-rated  pain (V AS), disability (NDI), and self-efficacy (Self-efficacy  scale). Results favored the NSE and NSEB groups over the PPA group(2) -At 3 months, most patients who had at least a 50% reduction in pain were in one of the two NSE groups (29%–48%) compared with the PPA group (5%). At 6 months most patients whocontinued to have at least a 50% reduction in pain were in one of the two NSE groups (39%–44%)  compared with the PPA group (28%) -NDI improved more in both the NSE and NSEB groups compared to the PPA group at 3 and 6 months -Self-efficacy  scores improved only in the NSE group -These results showed that neck-specific exercises can improve pain, disability, and self-efficacy.  The benefits of the addition of a behavioral component were inconclusive -In 2016,1-year  and 2-year  follow-up  of randomized subjects continued to favor the NSE and NSEB groups over the PPA group(29) -At 1year, most patients whohad at least a 50% reduction in pain were in one of the two NSE groups (61%) compared with the PPA group (26%). At 2years the difference was not significant -NDI scores improved more in the two NSE groups compared to the PPA group at 1 and 2-years.  The PPA group did not improve over time -Self-efficacy  scores did not show any significant differences between groups at 1- or 2-year  follow-up -In 2018, a secondary analysis of the primary study investigatedthe effect of the three treatments on work ability (measured by the Work Ability Index). Results were in favor of the NSE and NSEB groups over the PPAgroup(41) -Additional inclusion criteriawere those currently employed or employed at the time of the accident (N = 165 of the original 216) -Measures were taken at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months -Work ability improved significantly more in the NSEB group compared to the PPA group at 3-, 6-,and 12-month  time periods. The NSEB group was significantly better than only the NSE group at 12months -Work ability decreasedover time in the PPA group -In 2019, a secondary analysis evaluated the effect of the three treatments on health-related  quality of life (HRQoL). NSE and NSEB groups continued to show favorable results over the PPA group(45) -No additional criteria were needed and all data on the 216 patients was evaluated -Outcome measures included the EQ-5D3L (including the EQ-V AS)  and the SF-36v2 -The NSE and NSEB groups had better outcomes than the PPA on the EQ-V AS  and the SF-36  physical component but did not have a higher overall EQ-5D score -The authors noted the complexity of HRQoL, and other factors may need to be considered -In 2019, a secondary analysis evaluatedthe three treatment groups forheadache severity and frequency. NSE and NSEB showed favorable results over the PPA in this study as well(44) -Additional inclusion criteria were patients who reported a headache in the preceding week or headache at least from time to time (N = 188 out of the original 216)  -Outcome measures were pain measured by V AS of current headache, maximum headache in the preceding week, and headachein the preceding 24 hours -The NSE and NSEB groups had decreased headache both over time and compared to the PPA group. At 12 months 51% of the NSE group and 61% of the NSEB group reported at least a 50% reduction in their headache. The PPA group did not improve over time

Patient education –Patient education regarding the nature of the injury, course of recovery, maintaining daily activities, and coping strategies has proven effective. Exercises that reduce pain and improve active cervical ROM and cervical proprioception improve patient function. Behavioral-based  interventions should also play a role in the management of WAD(32,33) –Authors of a 2012 Cochrane review found no evidence to support educational interventions for chronic neck pain that include advice to become more active or advice on stress-coping  skills, workplace ergonomics, or self-care strategies(20)

Vestibular rehabilitation –Authors of a study (N = 40) foundthat vestibular rehabilitation in patients with WADcan be an effective treatment for dizziness and overall QOL(43) -Patients were randomly placed either into the intervention group or control group. The intervention group received 12 sessions of vestibular-balance  exercises. The outcome measures were the DHI and Smooth Pursuit Neck Torsion (SPNT) scores -In comparison to the control group, the intervention group showed significant improvements in the SPNT scores and the total score of the DHI -. Problem Goal Intervention Expected ProgressionHome Exercise Program Neck pain/tenderness Pain reduction or relief Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Soft collar for no more than 72 hours. Evidence indicatesthat prolonged immobilization delays healing(46) _ _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Thermal modalities for superficial heating or cooling _ _ Evidence is conflicting regarding the use of electrotherapeutic modalities in mechanical neck disorders(13)Progressive improvement in symptoms, mobility, sleep quality, and morning symptomsPatient education on occupational risk factors and use of hot or cold packs _ _ According to the Australian national guidelines for WAD, collars should not be used for more than 48 hours _ Educate patient on avoiding activities and positions that cause irritation  Deficits in cervical and thoracic ROMFull cervical and thoracic ROMPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Thermal modalities for superficial heating prior to stretching/ROM exercises _ _ Evidence is conflicting on the use of electrotherapeutic modalities in mechanical neck disorders to improve cervical function(13) _ _ Neck and scapulo- thoracic muscle stretching as indicatedProgress intensity and duration of exercises until normal flexibility is achievedAdvise patient to stay active and complete exercises as appropriate. Advise continuation of exercises after discharge Deficits in aerobic endurance and muscle strengthImproved muscular strength and enduranceTherapeutic exercise _ Individually prescribed aerobic activity (including walking and upper body ergometer) _ _ Neck and scapulo- thoracic muscle strengtheningProgress intensity and duration of exercises until normal strength is achievedProgress intensity and duration of exercises until normal strength is achieved Dizziness with associated functional deficits in balance and posture stabilityPatient free from dizziness, normal postural and balance reactions _ _Functional training _ Balance and posture reeducation exercises _ _ Head-turning exercises, vestibular gaze stability exercises, if indicatedProgress intensity until patient demonstrates normal postureProvide patient with written instructions regarding functional activities to be performed at home  Injury-related stress and anxiety _ _ _ _ _ _ Poor posture, body mechanics, and ergonomicsReferral for counseling on stress management _ _ _ _ _ Improved body mechanics, ergonomics, posture, and functional mobility _ Symmetry in head/ shoulder posture, sitting, and standingPatient education _ Lack of strong evidence to support psychological counseling and relaxation techniques(14) _ _ Posture exercises; training in body mechanics; ergonomic assessmentN/A _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ As indicatedN/A _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Instruct patient in home exercises to improve posture and body mechanics; implement ergonomic changes Reduced functional mobility and ability to perform ADLs or job dutiesImproved functional mobility, ADL performance, and ability to perform job dutiesFunctional mobility training with proper posture and body mechanics; work hardeningAs indicated N/A .

maintenance or prevention: Continue neck strengthening to maintain improved function(12)
Ergonometric assessment of workplace risk for chronic neck strain
Safe driving practices (e.g., seatbelt use and avoidance of texting while driving) can help reduce MV As and WADs(36)
